moves.1. d4 g6 2. c4 Bg7: A Modern opening that soon transposes into the Grunfeld.
moves.3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Nf3 d5: Strange, usually this is played before Bg7 but this will likely transpose into a normal Grunfeld.
moves.5. cxd5 Nxd5 6. Bd2: This is an interesting move I picked up from my chess coach Vojislav Milanovic. The idea is to take on c3 with the bishop to effectively prevent a future c5.
moves.6... O-O 7. e4 Nxc3 8. Bxc3 Nc6: This is the right idea but the wrong move. Much better is c5 to put instant pressure on the center and then to maybe follow up with Nc6.
moves.9... Bg4: Trying to undermine d4 by eliminating one of its defenders.
moves.12... c6 13. f4: I plan to take control of the center, play Bxg7 and then castle.
Keeping good pawn structure and central control.
moves.16... e6: Just giving me a free pawn with very little (if any) compensation.
moves.18. Qxa7 Qc8 19. b3 Nb6 20. Rac1: Taking control of the open c-file.
moves.22... Qb2 23. Bf3: Preparing to open up the h1-a8 diagonal at an opportune moment.
moves.23... Kg8: I think my opponent was afraid of the maneuver Qa5-c3+ to trade queens and go into a winning endgame.
moves.24. Qa5 Nd7 25. Qd2: Offering a trade of queens. Black is forced to accept or he loses his d7 knight.
moves.25... Qxd2 26. Rxd2 Nb6: White has a much better position and is winning.
moves.27. a4: My idea is to play a5 and then march the a pawn all the way down the board to queen it.
moves.28... Nb6 29. a5 Na4: Hoping I will take on a4. Of course I see through the trap.
moves.30. b4 Nc3 31. Rb3 Nb5: Establishing the knight on a good square.
moves.32. e5: I plan to play something along the lines of Bc6 and eliminating the knight.
moves.35... Rb8 36. b6 Na6 37. Bb5: Trying to get rid of the knight.
